title: Do newspapers tell you if they are going to publish your letter? - Quora

response.answer_text: Many newspapers will phone you to verify that you really did write the letter that has your name on it. That means they’re considering it for publication, but not necessarily that it will be published.
Generally, if I or the news clerk called a letter writer to confirm authorship, that was a sign we planned to print it. My more frequent writers often called me.

Only once has this happened to me, when I asked the publisher not to use my name to protect the privacy of my daughter who’d been sexually molested by a male teacher. My letter stated (correctly) that the teacher in question had been charged, convicted, and sentenced to perform “community service”, which he’d chosen to fulfill as the local District Commissioner for Boy Scouts. My letter asked the question: What kind of leader of men and boys would he, a convicted sex-offender, make? What attitudes would he impart if he felt it was acceptable for a teacher to molest a young girl? Of course, the newly appointed commissioner’s name was widely known in the community, so there was no attempt to hide his identity. The publisher contacted me only to verify the truth of what I claimed and after investigating, he published my letter without my name. I’ve had a fair number of letters published in local and national newspapers but that is the only time the paper contacted me prior to printing.
The one I work for calls to verify your identity then publishes. If there is some reason not to publish it, they’ll inform you.
